pageContext.description: The theme of the ill-matched couple enjoys a long tradition in Western culture, above all in the literary world, although it did not appear in the visual arts until the last quarter of the fifteenth century, reaching the heights of its popularity during the first half of the following one, particularly in Germany and Flanders. In this tradition, the woman is presented as a dangerous creature, a source of sin, humiliation, perdition and death. The theme, the origins of which date from the Middle Ages, was subsequently reformulated and led to a host of variations. This particular version depicts the couple alone, against a plain background that gives no indication of where the action is taking place: an imprudent old man, thoroughly captivated by female charms. The theme of the ill-matched couple was one of Lucas Cranach's favourites, and was frequently copied by his contemporaries and followers.
